Group

A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Ring

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Units of a Ring
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
Ring Isomorphism

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
Ring Endomorphism
An endomorphism of a ring $R$ is a homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
A-homomorphism
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
Rank of an A-module
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Degree of a Field Extension

Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension. The vector space dimension $[L: K]:=\operatorname{dim}_{K} L$ is called the degree of $L$ over $K$. The field extension is called finite or infinite, depending on whether $[L: K]$ is finite or infinite.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Galois extension
An extension $K_{r} / K$ is Galois if it is both normal and separable.
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.
Set
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A group is defined as a monoid with additional properties. Therefore, the concept of a monoid must be defined to understand what a group is.
A ring is defined as a set with two operations that satisfy certain properties. Therefore, the concept of a set must be defined to understand what a ring is.
The units of a ring are defined as the multiplicatively invertible elements of a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what the units of a ring are.
A ring isomorphism is defined as a bijective ring homomorphism that admits an inverse. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring isomorphism is.
A ring endomorphism is defined as a homomorphism from a ring to itself. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring endomorphism is.
A-homomorphisms are defined as homomorphisms between A-modules. Therefore, the concept of an A-module must be defined to understand what an A-homomorphism is.

The rank of an A-module is defined as the supremum of the number of linearly independent elements in the module. Therefore, the concept of an A-module must be defined to understand what the rank of an A-module is.

The degree of a field extension is defined as the dimension of the extension as a vector space over the base field. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what the degree of a field extension is.

The Galois group of a finite field extension is defined as the group of field automorphisms that fix the base field. Therefore, the concept of a finite field extension must be defined to understand what the Galois group is.
A Galois extension is defined as a field extension that is both normal and separable. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what a Galois extension is.
The sign or signature of a permutation is defined in terms of the elements of a set. Therefore, the concept of a set must be defined to understand what the sign of a permutation is.
